job_title: Anonymous Employee in Gwynedd Valley, PA
pros: The Critical Concerns of the Sisters of Mercy are present throughout every initiative at the university and can give its employees a sense of community, and participation in something greater. The university offers a generous leave policy, flexible summer hours program, 100% tuition remission (including dependents), and other attractive benefits.
cons: The university is plagued with a series of systematic issues. Pay is significantly lower than comparable institutions in the area, and there are issues with attracting and retaining staff. Hiring decisions are not equitable and based on qualifications, but are based on the whims of the search committee, upper-level administration, and who you know already there. HR is marginally functional, frequently "missing" (ignoring) emails and turning a basic task such as updating your phone # into an arduous ordeal. Ineffective management, disorganized departments, and toxic behaviors go unchecked. The on-campus undergraduate programs academics-wise are okay, but the online graduate programs are sub-par and poorly administered (outside of the EDD program).

review_title: No Integrity and a Toxic Environment
pros: Many faculty are truly dedicated to excellent teaching.
cons: The university is desperate for students, who are then coddled, catered to, and passed through the curriculum in an effort to keep them. Personally know of several instances in which students were "given" passing grades for classes they did not take or failed. Plagiarism is often overlooked by both faculty and administrators. Unprofessional relationships between faculty and administration. For example, some faculty are allowed to call into meetings while others (same department / same meeting) are not.
